content.description: Sit start with good left hand edge and a potato chip right hand. From there, pull up through edges to reach an easy mantel.
content.protection: A pad or two. This is problem is short, but there are some rocks in the landing.
content.location: It climbs the southeast face of Breaker.

content.description: Sit start matched on the edge. From there, make a big move straight out to a jug, match on it, move to the jug above, gain the bumps high on the lip, and mantel atop the boulder.
content.protection: A pad or two. The landing is good, but there is a rock that makes it slightly uneven.
content.location: It climbs the northeast face of Breaker.

content.description: Sit start with a pair of edges. From there, gain the jug above, then climb through edges to reach an easy mantel.
content.protection: A pad will work. It has a good landing as long as you don't fall on the boulder to the right.
content.location: It climbs the north arete of Breaker.

content.description:
GTTL climbs solid stone over a decent landing. Small hands and big feet are the theme.

Sit start matched on the jugs. From there, crank up with a right heel to a right hand crimp, match a left hand next to it, traverse right to a decent edge, stick the shelf above, commit to the slab, and top it out.
content.protection: A pair of pads. The start has some rocks to the left, but it pads well.
content.location: It climbs the northwest face of Breaker.

content.description:
Sit start matched on an edge just to the right of the rock. From there, stick a big move to the jug, match on it, use a gaggle of edges to reach the jug on the face, and finish up the remaining slab.

This problem surprised me. I imagined the rock at the start would totally ruin the movement, but it had no effect with my experience.
content.protection: At least a pair of pads. The landing pad really well, but there are some rocks.
content.location: It climbs the center of Breaker's northeast face.
